content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really like this type of problem

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool clash. As stated by @User123, the tricky part is handling the last element in A, especially in the shortest code challenge.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and fun clash :) Conditional handling of last element in friend_A may be tricky for beginners.

- Consider rephrasing the description of friend_A and friend_B as "The space-separated string containing <<all>> the words said by Friend _ across the entire game".

- Please add a constraint where the number of words in friend_A is at most 1 more than the number of words in friend_B, in accordance with the rule of the One Word Game.

- Consider clarifying that a word may contain uppercase and/or lowercase English letters and/or punctuation, but never spaces; spaces will always be reserved to separate words in each string.

- I believe that specifying the number of words explicitly for each string is preferred to avoid disadvantaging clashers coding in languages such as C, so I would suggest to add the total number of words per string into the input. I could be mistaken though.

Regarding @User123's suggestions:
- point 1: Agreed

- point 2: Agreed

- point 3: Agreed. However, since the final constraint implies that essentially all ASCII printable characters may appear in the input, I suggest simplifying @User123's suggested wording by replacing "punctuation, but never spaces" with "other non-space characters".

- point 4: Agreed. You're not mistaken at all! The issue is so common on CG that I hesitate to bring it up at all‚Ä¶

Additional comments from me:

Input
* Please remove the note and revise the description according to @User123's suggestion in point 1.

Output
* Please state "separated by a space".

Constraints
* Please delete the final constraint ("Both strings‚Ä¶ included") and rewrite it following @User123's suggestion in point 3.

Cases
* "Call a Bondulance" (Test 4): Please delete the third input line.

Thanks.

Thank you both for the feedback! I've made some quick fixes and will get to adding that extra input for the number of words in each string.

Edit: This is done. Just noticed basically all the test cases unintentionally have an equal number of words said by both friends, so I'll probably make a few more cases for variation.

Thanks @Anqilique, please also fix the test Not-A-Story (and its corresponding validator) as they both violate the constraint on words_A and words_B (you can just relax that constraint if that helps).

Perhaps also add words_A and words_B before providing the word sequences friends_A and friends_B?

I would also like to further specify my previous suggestion on the words constraint; the exact constraint now should be [[words_A]] ‚â§ [[words_B]] ‚â§ [[words_A]] + 1.
Definitely add words_A and words_B before, and update the stub generator as well so that those integers are used in the parsing of friend_A and friend_B (with `loopline` instead of `read`. Thanks.

I've made the changes. It is a good idea that the word counts come first.

I've had a go at updating the stub generator, though I'm not too sure if it's correct (first contribution/time working with this üòÖ).

It's correct üëç

Constraints
* Please simplify the constraints by changing the first inequality to (oh, please also note that the order of the variables in the inequality should be revised):

1 ‚â§ [[words_B]] ‚â§ [[words_A]] ‚â§ [[words_B]] + 1

and deleting:

The string friend_A contains at least one word.
The string friend_B contains at least one word.

* Please replace the second and third inequalities with:

1 ‚â§ number of characters of each word in [[friend_A]] and [[friend_B]] ‚â§ 10

* Consider deleting the three headings (Number of Words, Number of Characters and Other) after the constraints have been simplified.

Stub generator
* Both "50"s can be changed to 10 (if all words are 10 characters long or shorter).

Cases
* Currently only the last validator is a case where words_A > words_B. Also, digits are always standalone words in the third pair of cases.

  Would you please create a new pair of cases in which:

  ‚Ä¢ words_A > words_B, and
  ‚Ä¢ digits form part of a word?

  There are several ways in which digits may form part of a word, involving different combinations of letters, digits, and punctuation. For example:
  ‚Ä¢ 24/7
  ‚Ä¢ $731k
  ‚Ä¢ v2.0
  ‚Ä¢ Y2K
  ‚Ä¢ win32
  ‚Ä¢ A4
  ‚Ä¢ H2O
  ‚Ä¢ 1984
  ‚Ä¢ 3D printer
  ‚Ä¢ the above examples or similar combinations + punctuation

  Please construct new cases using patterns such as these.

Thanks.
Finally got around to doing this. +2 test cases that should follow those requirements and their validators. Thanks for the feedback!

No problem! And we're getting close!

For these two cases:
‚Ä¢ Darling, Hold My Hand (Test 5)
‚Ä¢ Digits Part of Words (Validator 5)

* Please avoid using the character ¬£, as it's not always easy to write code that reliably handles non-ASCII characters in some programming languages. Consider changing it to $.

* Please avoid using real or near-real brand names such as Jet2holiday. It'd be better to replace them with something similar but clearly fictional (e.g. Walk2holiday).
  
* Your two new case pairs capture most numerical patterns, but they don't yet include numbers with 2 or more digits. Can you add one in Test 5 and one in Validator 5 (or another pair of cases of your choice)?

Thanks.
üëç IDE's working again. Modified Test + Validator 5 as suggested, also added a new pair of cases just for the larger numbers.
